latest news.eng_title: Could This Be the Start of Amazon's Next Robot Revolution?
latest news.summary: Amazon has acquired the founders of Covariant, a startup that has been testing ways for AI to automate the picking and handling of a wide range of physical objects. The deal, which will also see Amazon license Covariant's models and data, could bring about another revolution in ecommerce, one that might prove hard for any competitor to match given Amazon's vast operational scale and data trove. Covariant has developed AI algorithms with a more general ability to handle a range of items more reliably, and the company's models will be used to power some of the robotic manipulation systems across Amazon's fulfillment network, according to Alexandra Miller, an Amazon spokesperson. The deal is an example of a Big Tech company acquiring core talent and expertise from an AI startup without actually buying the company outright, and it follows similar agreements with startups Adept and Inflection. Amazon's acquisition of Kiva Systems in 2012 also kickstarted a wider revolution in warehouse automation, and the company's mobile robot army has grown from around 10,000 in 2013 to 750,000 by 2023.
latest news.title: Could This Be the Start of Amazon's Next Robot Revolution?

latest news.eng_title: Until Dawn remake dev hit by bone-deep layoffs just a month before the game comes out
latest news.summary: Just a month before the release of the Until Dawn remake on PC, the UK studio Ballistic Moon has been hit by significant layoffs. According to a statement on LinkedIn, the studio has 'scaled down' its team to secure its future. Former devs have taken to social media to announce their redundancies, including Harry Williams, who said, 'After two exciting years working on the wonderful Until Dawn 2024 at Ballistic Moon I am unfortunately being made redundant as a Technical Designer.' The layoffs come amidst a wave of job cuts in the games industry, with over 16,000 layoffs reported this year alone. The Until Dawn remake is set to launch on October 4, developed using Unreal Engine 5. 'As is currently the way of things,' said former gameplay programmer Rudi Prentice, 'I've unfortunately been made redundant at Ballistic Moon.'
latest news.title: Until Dawn remake dev hit by bone-deep layoffs just a month before the game comes out

latest news.eng_title: 2 No-Brainer Stocks I'd Buy Right Now Without Hesitation
latest news.summary: Two companies, CrowdStrike and Amazon, are considered 'no-brainer buys' by experts due to their long-term potential. CrowdStrike, a cybersecurity company, has faced short-term challenges, including a global IT outage, but its recent quarter results show the business is still thriving, with $3.8 billion in annual recurring revenue and a 32% year-over-year growth. Amazon, on the other hand, has a strong e-commerce business and a leading cloud service, Amazon Web Services (AWS), which generated $26.3 billion in revenue and $9.3 billion in operating income in its latest quarter. Experts believe that AWS will continue to lead the market and that Amazon is a cornerstone piece in many investors' portfolios. 'It's not easy for companies to completely change cybersecurity providers,' said an expert, 'and considering CrowdStrike's problem wasn't the result of a cyberattack, I don't believe customers will lose faith in the effectiveness of its product.'

latest news.eng_title: Tech Industry Sees Layoffs Surge To 27,000 In August, Highest Since January
latest news.summary: The tech industry experienced a significant surge in layoffs in August 2024, with 44 companies collectively laying off 27,065 employees. This represents the highest level of job cuts since January of this year. The layoffs were primarily driven by substantial reductions at prominent industry leaders like Intel and Cisco. Intel announced 15,000 job cuts, equating to 15% of its workforce, as part of a broader cost-saving strategy. Cisco also announced significant layoffs, reducing its workforce by 5,900, representing about 7% of its total staff. Additionally, German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon announced plans to eliminate 1,400 jobs globally and relocate an additional 1,400 positions to countries with lower labor costs. IBM also announced the closure of its research and development operations in China, a move expected to impact over 1,000 jobs.

latest news.eng_title: Amazon Adds to Its Warehouse Robotics Prowess in Deal with Covariant
latest news.summary: Amazon has announced a deal with Covariant, a California-based developer of robots for distribution. As part of the deal, Amazon will hire three Covariant founders and receive a non-exclusive license to Covariant's AI models. The deal is similar to one Amazon struck in June with Adept, a startup building AI agents that automate enterprise workflows. Covariant's robots leverage a platform called the 'Covariant Brain' and have been deployed by the tens of thousands at Amazon's fulfillment centers. The deal comes as Amazon faces increased scrutiny over worker safety, with a 2019 report showing a higher injury rate at Amazon's robotic fulfillment centers than at its older facilities. Amazon has disputed the notion that robots boost injury rates, citing lower recordable incident rates and lost-time incident rates at its robotics sites compared to non-robotics sites in 2022. 'I want to eliminate the mundane, and the tedious, and the repetitive,' said Ty Brady, the chief technologist for Amazon Robotics. 'I want to make things safer inside our fulfillment centers.' Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. The deal is seen as a 'reverse acquihire,' where Amazon is hiring the founders and employees of Covariant while also licensing its technology. This is the second such deal Amazon has made in recent months, following a similar deal with Adept in June.
latest news.title: Amazon Adds to Its Warehouse Robotics Prowess in Deal with Covariant

latest news.eng_title: Amazon bolsters warehouse automation with key talent acquisition
latest news.summary: Amazon has acquired key talent from robotics software developer Covariant, including its founders and approximately 25% of its staff, to bolster its warehouse automation efforts. The acquisition forms part of Amazon's commitment to warehouse automation, exemplified by its 2012 purchase of Kiva Systems. Covariant's expertise lies in developing advanced AI models that equip robots with the ability to 'see, reason, and act' within their environment. Amazon has also secured a nonexclusive license to Covariant's foundational robotic models, which will contribute to the further development and refinement of Amazon's in-house automation solutions. This move holds significant implications for the future of e-commerce fulfilment, potentially leading to faster order processing times and improved operational efficiency for Amazon and other companies leveraging similar technologies.
latest news.title: Amazon bolsters warehouse automation with key talent acquisition

latest news.eng_title: Infineon to Lay Off 1,400 Employees, Transfer Positions to Countries with Lower Labor Costs
latest news.summary: Infineon Technologies, the leading German chip manufacturer, announced on Monday that it will lay off 1,400 employees worldwide and transfer 1,400 positions to countries with lower labor costs as part of its previously announced cost-cutting program. The job cuts will include several hundred positions at Infineon's plant in Regensburg. The company aims to improve operational efficiency and reduce costs by relocating operations to regions with significantly lower labor costs. Infineon's decision comes at a time when the semiconductor industry is experiencing rapid changes and facing various challenges. The global demand for semiconductors has increased due to the growth of technologies such as artificial intelligence, electric vehicles, and advanced telecommunications. However, this increased demand has also highlighted weaknesses in supply chains and the need for companies to optimize their operations to remain competitive. The announcement coincided with a significant sell-off in Taiwan's stock market, with the Taiex index falling by over 8% to 19,830.88. Major tech firms including Amazon and Microsoft also experienced significant losses, contributing to the market downturn. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), a major player in the global semiconductor industry, saw its shares fall by 9.3%. TSMC, which controls more than half of the world's silicon wafer production, has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of the artificial intelligence-driven technology rally. The company's stock price briefly surpassed $1 trillion in July, making it the seventh most valuable tech company, ahead of Tesla. Despite recent market fluctuations, TSMC reported a strong financial performance, with profits increasing by over 30% in the second quarter and revenues rising by 32% to $20.82 billion. The company is expected to exceed analyst expectations for its third-quarter revenue, which is forecast to reach $23.2 billion. TSMC's major customers, including Apple, Nvidia, and AMD, are at the center of the current surge in productive artificial intelligence products, driven by the success of ChatGPT. However, concerns about the sustainability of the artificial intelligence-driven rally have sparked speculation that technology stock valuations may be too high and potentially lead to a correction in the market. Infineon's layoffs and relocations are part of a broader strategy to improve efficiency and remain competitive in the dynamic semiconductor industry. Meanwhile, the recent market sales in Taiwan reflect broader economic uncertainties and concerns about technology stock valuations. As the semiconductor industry continues to evolve, companies like Infineon and TSMC must overcome these challenges to sustain growth and profitability.

news knowledge.eng_title: Eletrobras Launches New Layoff Program with Incentives
news knowledge.summary: Eletrobras has launched a new Programa de Demissão Consensual Incentivada (Consensual Incentivized Layoff Program) for employees who want to leave the company but did not qualify for the previous Programas de Demissão Voluntárias (Voluntary Layoff Programs). The program is limited to employees who signed the new Acordo Coletivo de Trabalho (ACT 2024-26) and is currently only available to Eletrobras Eletronorte employees in the Amazonas state and Eletrobras Chesf employees in the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceará, Paraíba, Piauí, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe. According to Eletrobras, the program offers a year's worth of fixed remuneration, 'to allow professionals to organize their career transition'; indemnifications up to R$ 500,000; and a 9-month health plan. Without the program, employees would be laid off without indemnification and the health plan would be extended for a maximum of 3 months, Eletrobras explained. The deadline for applications is August 30, and the company may accept or reject each employee's resignation. The effective date for voluntary layoffs will be September 30, with the possibility of extension to October 30 in exceptional cases, as stated by the company.

news knowledge.eng_title: The US companies in the tech sector with the largest mass layoffs since 2020
news knowledge.summary: The tech industry experienced significant job instability following the COVID-19 pandemic, with major companies like Amazon, Meta, and Apple initiating large-scale layoffs. Google's January 2023 layoff of 12,000 employees was the largest single layoff event in the tech sector since 2020. In 2023, nearly 2,000 tech companies laid off over 260,000 employees, and the trend continued into 2024. Despite these layoffs, the stocks of Google, Meta, and Microsoft have risen significantly, with Microsoft reaching a valuation of $3 trillion earlier this year. According to Jeff Shulman, a professor at the University of Washington's Foster School of Business, 'there is a herding effect in tech,' where layoffs seem to help stock prices, leading companies to continue laying off employees. The low unionization rate in the tech industry, at 1% in 2022, further reduces workers' bargaining power.
